channel.title: Xen In ep3?
channel.description: I was just wondering about this after playing blue shift for the 3rd time in a row. In order to use the teleporting technology they had to use a special beckon in Xen in order to swing around it to your intended destination. Well when I was activating the beckon I noticed that there was a rather small generator there to power the beckon and that beckon was left on for 20+ years and in use for about 3 trips. So what if in ep3 you're trying to teleport for whatever reason and the beckon is inactive and instead of swinging around you just end up crashing into Xen? What do you guys think? :retard:

item.title: Xen In ep3?
item.dc:creator: Muhb
item.description:
@ xalener: That first sentence. You said exactly what I was thinking but was too nice to say… hi five? :lol:

@ Dias: I agree with the idea that it’s (generally) very terrible practice to throw gamers in a situation they haven’t had practice in before, and expect them to just “get it.” Unfortunately, that’s pretty much what Valve did with Xen… If they were to go back in EP3 or later, I would expect them to either introduce the player to the mechanics of it at least a little bit differently this time, or maybe just design the maps a bit differently.

However, at the same time, I strongly disagree with the statement that first-person platforming “just isn’t fun.” I think that it can be, when done right. Portal did it right. Parts of the Metroid Prime trilogy did it right, IMHO. In the end, I don’t think there’s much cause to be worried over Xen even if Valve does decide to take us back, (which, I hate to say, is probably very unlikely… oh well) because they would hopefully have smoothed over the issues of HL1’s Xen by then.

And Mirror’s Edge was awesome. :what:

item.title: Xen In ep3?
item.dc:creator: Dias
item.description:
coldroll:

What if we could see it in one of gman’s flashbacks?

If that’s the case, then who cares?

xalener:

Because they sucked at it back then?

When I say “they” I mean everyone.

The players sucked at fp platforming because it was a new thing.

This is not how game design works at all. You shouldn’t make a game with the expectation that players will have had practice with the mechanics already.

Ever notice how portal held your hand through everything? Not even letting you get the portal gun until the third chamber & giving you the other portal after almost another 10 levels. First-person platforming just isn’t fun or interesting (& yes I played Mirrors Edge & it sucked). Now tell me why Valve would waste so much effort into that crap in Episode 3, when they could make it more like Episode 2 & be a dozen times less likely to suck?
